Award.AwardTitle: Conference Support for the Second International Workshop on Nano-Micro Thermal Radiation (NanoRad2014), June 6-9, 2014 in Shanghai, China

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1445442
Zhang


This proposal requests support for several junior faculty members, a graduate student, and a plenary speaker attending the conference. The conference is scheduled to be held June 6-9, 2014 in Shanghai, China. The main objective of this proposal is to support participation at the Conference Support for the Second International Workshop on Nano-Micro Thermal Radiation. The workshop will bring together experts in thermal radiative transfer worldwide along with young researchers and students for close interactions and discussions. A short course will be offered in conjunction with the workshop. Young scholars and graduate students attending this course will gain a better understanding of the fundamentals as well as deep appreciation of the current research trends in this field.

Nano-microscale thermal radiation has important applications in energy harvesting such as solar cells and thermophotovoltaics, nanomanufacturing, biomedical sensing, and thermal imaging and locating heating below the diffraction limit. Radiative heat transfer can be greatly enhanced at nanometer distances due to photon tunneling and the excitation of surface plasmon (or phonon) polaritons. Furthermore, the performance of various devices can be greatly enhanced by the modification of the reflection, transmission, absorption and emission spectra using one-, two-, or three-dimensional micro/nanostructures.

This workshop will bring together experts, researchers, and students from around the world for an open exchange of research ideas, recent findings and discoveries, and future outlooks in Nano and Micro Thermal Radiation. This event will provide a forum to facilitate international collaboration and promote joint efforts in this multidisciplinary area. Abstracts and PowerPoint slides from the workshop will available to the participants. The most recent progress and development results will be published in a special issue of JQSRT following the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Second International Workshop on Nano-Micro Thermal Radiation: Energy, Manufacturing, Materials, and Sensing (NanoRad2014) was held on June 6-9, 2014 in Shanghai, China. It was organized by Shanghai University of Electric Power (China) and Harbin Institute of Technology (China). Professor Zhuomin Zhang of Georgia Institute of Technology was the Chair and Professors Linhua Liu of Harbin Institute of Technology and Professor Qunzhi Zhu of Shanghai University of Electric Power were Vice-Chairs. The workshop was sponsored by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 51410105006) and the US National Science Foundation (CBET-1445442). The support by NSF has enabled the attendance of several organizers, young faculty members, and students from the United States.

NanoRad2014 has brought together some 90 experts, researchers, and students from around the globe for open discussions on the recent research findings and discoveries as well as future directions of nano/microscale thermal radiative transfer and related radiative properties. It has provided a valuable forum to facilitate international collaborations and promote joint efforts in this multidisciplinary research field. During NanoRad2014 workshop, keynote lectures were given by Professor Shigenao Maruyama (Tohoku University, Japan) and Professor Yimin Xuan (Nanjing University of Aeronautics & Astronautics, China). There were two keynote speeches and over 41 oral and 12 poster presentations. A one-and-half-day Short Course on Introduction to Micro/Nano Thermal Radiation was also held in conjunction with the workshop on June 4-5, 2014. Furthermore, the 2014 Elsevier/JQSRT Raymond Viskanta Young Scientist Award was presented at this workshop to Professor Sheng Shen (Carnegie Mellon University, USA).

Micro and nano-scale thermal radiation has become one of the fastest growing research areas because of advances in nanotechnology and the development of novel materials. Radiative heat transfer can be greatly enhanced at nanometer distances due to photon tunneling and the excitation of surface plasmon (or phonon) polaritons. Furthermore, the performance of various devices can be greatly enhanced by the modification of the reflection, transmission, absorption and emission spectra using one-, two-, or three-dimensional micro/nanostructures. The research works cover a broad range of topics on near-field radiative transfer including hyperbolic metamaterials, fishnet metamaterials, graphene surface plasmons, nanoparticles and surface roughness effect, surface plasmon polaritons, surface phonon polaritons, and solid-state phase-change materials and novel computational techniques. Spectral and directional control of the radiative properties using nanostructured materials and surfaces is another main thrust. Examples are metamaterials with dielectric inclusion, graphitic nanopetal arrays, aligned carbon nanotubes, porous aluminum foams, photonics crystals, and other periodic structures. First principles have been used to study the dielectric properties of nanostructured materials. The applications of these studies range from solar energy, thermophotovoltaic, nanomanufacturing, thermal diode, materials processing, and imaging. Selected papers were reviewed and published in a special issue of the Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer (June 2015).
